user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetLocalTime_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GetLocalTime_Impl(OS_time_t *time_struct)
{
    int             Status;
    int32           ReturnCode;
    struct timespec TimeSp;

    Status = clock_gettime(OSAL_GETTIME_SOURCE_CLOCK, &TimeSp);

    if (Status == 0)
    {
        *time_struct = OS_TimeAssembleFromNanoseconds(TimeSp.tv_sec, TimeSp.tv_nsec);
        ReturnCode   = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error calling clock_gettime: %s\n", strerror(errno));
        ReturnCode = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return ReturnCode;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
*time_struct = OS_TimeAssembleFromNanoseconds(TimeSp.tv_sec, TimeSp.tv_nsec);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: time_struct is used as an output parameter (the object it points to is assigned), so the pointer must not be to a const-qualified type. A violation would occur if the function only read from the pointed-to object — e.g. if the code only accessed members of time_struct without modifying them — in which case the parameter should be declared as const OS_time_t *time_struct.
